title: The Night Market
description: Shilin Night Market. Taipei. 11 PM. A woman in red offers you a deal. Nothing here is what it seems, including you.

scenes.title: The Offer
scenes.content:
You're lost on purpose when she finds you.

Red dress. Heels that shouldn't work on wet pavement. Smile that doesn't reach her eyes.

"You're looking for something." Statement, not question. "Everyone who wanders Shilin alone at midnight is looking for something."

Behind her, a stall sells wooden masks. They seem to be watching.

"I can help you find it. But you'll have to tell me what it is first."

choices.text: "My friend disappeared here six months ago."

scenes.title: Just a Tourist
scenes.content:
"Nobody's just anything."

She produces a business card from nowhere. Blank except for an address.

"When you're ready to stop lying to yourself, come find me." She's already turning away. "The market remembers everyone who walks through it. And everyone leaves something behind."

Gone. Like smoke.

The card's warm in your pocket. You tell yourself you'll throw it away.

You don't.

scenes.title: The Disappeared
scenes.content:
Her expression shifts. Recognition.

"The American. Marcus Chen. Asked too many questions about things that weren't his business." She starts walking, expecting you to follow. "I know where he went. Question is whether finding him makes things better or worse."

The market noise fades as she leads you deeper. Past the tourist stalls. Past the locals-only noodle joints. Into alleys where the neon doesn't reach.

"Your friend found something he shouldn't have. People who find things like that usually end up unfound themselves."

scenes.title: The Price
scenes.content:
"Smart." She stops, turns. The alley light catches her face wrong. "Most people don't ask until after."

"So what is it?"

"A secret. One you've never told anyone." She steps closer. "The more valuable the secret, the more I can help."

"And if I don't have secrets?"

"Everyone has secrets. The only question is whether they're worth anything."

choices.text: Tell her something small, test the waters

scenes.title: The Real Secret
scenes.content:
You tell her about Marcus. What you didn't tell the police. What you didn't tell his family.

You were supposed to come with him. He asked you three times. You said no because you were scared, because Taipei felt too far, because you had a job and a lease and all the excuses people make when they're afraid of their own lives.

He came alone because you let him.

She absorbs this without expression.

"Guilt. Good currency here." She gestures toward a door you hadn't noticed. "He's through there. Alive, last I checked. But he won't thank you for finding him."

scenes.title: Something Small
scenes.content:
You tell her about a time you cheated on an exam in college. Organic chemistry. Copied off the girl next to you. Never told anyone.

She laughs. Actually laughs.

"That's adorable. You came all this way to find your missing friend and you think freshman chemistry is going to open any doors?"

Her smile is sharper now. Less friendly.

"Come back when you're ready to pay real prices. The market doesn't take loose change."

She walks away. You're alone in an alley that doesn't appear on Google Maps, and you're pretty sure you just failed some kind of test.

choices.text: Call out, tell her the truth

scenes.title: Walking Away
scenes.content:
"Smart choice." Her voice follows you. "Or coward's choice. Time will tell."

You find your way back to the bright lights, the food stalls, the normal world. Buy some fried chicken to prove everything's fine.

It's not fine. You leave Taiwan the next morning.

Marcus stays missing. The police file stays open. And sometimes, in that space between sleep and waking, you see her face and wonder what was behind that door.

Some questions don't get answers. You learn to live with that.

Sort of.

scenes.title: Behind the Door
scenes.content:
Warehouse. Old one, converted into something between an office and a temple. Incense and electronics. Servers humming next to shrines.

Marcus is at a desk, typing. He looks up when you enter.

"Took you long enough."

He's thinner. Eyes different. Not scared, exactly. More like someone who's seen past the edge of something and decided to keep looking.

"Everyone's worried," you manage.

"Everyone should mind their business." He turns back to the screen. "I found what I was looking for. Now I'm working on it."

"Working on what?"

"The underneath. The real market. The one where information is the only currency that matters."

scenes.title: What He Found
scenes.content:
"The night market is a front. Or not a front exactly. More like a membrane." Marcus pulls up screens faster than you can follow. "On top: tourists, food, normal commerce. Underneath: everything else."

Photos. Documents. Transaction records.

"Every major intelligence service has people here. Every corporation. Every organization that deals in what people don't want found. They all trade in the same market, just different stalls."

He looks at you.

"Your friend in red? She's a broker. Matches buyers and sellers. Secrets for secrets. Information for information. She was testing you to see which side you belonged on."

"Which side is that?"

"The side that pays. Or the side that gets paid." He shrugs. "I started as a buyer. Now I'm something in between."

scenes.title: The Offer (Lin)
scenes.content:
The woman in red appears like she was always there.

"He's good," she says, nodding at Marcus. "Better than we expected. But we could use someone with your particular... guilt complex."

"My what?"

"You came all this way because you feel responsible. That means you're loyal. Loyal people are valuable here."

Marcus doesn't look up from his screen.

"It's not a bad life," he says. "Better than whatever you were doing before."

The warehouse hums around you. Incense and electricity. Secrets buying secrets.

choices.text: "I came to bring him home, not join a cult."

scenes.title: I'm In
scenes.content:
Three months later, you have a desk next to Marcus. A new phone with encryption you don't fully understand. A life that looks normal from the outside and isn't.

The woman in red—her name is Lin, you learn eventually—brings you assignments. Small stuff at first. Translating documents. Verifying sources. Nothing that feels illegal until suddenly everything does.

"Everyone in the market has a price," Lin tells you once. "The only difference is what currency they accept."

You've stopped asking about the ethics. The information trade doesn't care about ethics. It cares about value.

Some nights, you remember the person you used to be. The one who thought organic chemistry cheating was a serious moral failing.

That person feels like a stranger now.

scenes.title: Coming Home
scenes.content:
"I'm not leaving," Marcus says. "But you should."

It's 3 AM. The warehouse is quiet. Just the two of you and the glow of screens.

"I found what I was looking for," he continues. "I'm exactly where I need to be. But you came here out of guilt, not curiosity. That's not enough to keep you going."

You want to argue. Can't.

"Lin will let you leave. You're not deep enough to be dangerous." He finally looks at you. "Go home. Tell everyone I'm fine. Tell them I found a job I love."

"Is that true?"

"True enough."

Two days later, you're on a plane. The night market shrinks to a story you'll tell at parties, edited for casual consumption.

Marcus sends encrypted emails sometimes. Holiday photos from places you don't recognize. He seems happy.

You learn to stop asking questions you don't want answered.

scenes.title: If I Say No
scenes.content:
"Then you walk away." Lin shrugs. "We're not monsters. We just trade in things more valuable than money."

You look at Marcus. He won't meet your eyes.

"But," Lin continues, "you'll forget most of this conversation by morning. Not magic, just chemistry. The tea you drank when you came in. Very mild. Very effective."

Your vision's already fuzzy at the edges.

"Sweet dreams," she says. "Remember us fondly. Or don't remember us at all."

You wake up in your hotel room with a headache and a vague sense you're forgetting something important. Flight's in six hours.

Marcus stays missing. The file stays open.

Some doors, once closed, don't open again.
